instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
I have another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that is having a similar issue as one I had previously posted about except this one had liquid damage. The customer said it came in contact with rain and they had the corrosion cleaned at a local shop(looked like they just ipa and brushed it and not ultrasonic). I ultrasonic'd the board and still no change.
Previous board with similar issue:  [URL="https://www.rossmanngroup.com/boards/forum/board-repair-troubleshooting/21084-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-pulsing-voltages-not-turning-on"]https://www.rossmanngroup.com/boards...not-turning-on[/URL]

Customer's Note: "It was water damaged in moderate rain, left vertical in a backpack. An anti-corrosion treatment at Retech saw it working again for a month before the working laptop stopped charging and the battery drained."

I get a green light that turns orange so I assume 3v42 is fine.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> starts at 13.69v(not sure why its so high) then quickly goes down to around 3v then back up to 13.69v and repeats
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/S3/S0, <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> all keep cycling from there original voltages.
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> looks good and Pin 2 also cycles. <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> looks like there was liquid near there but no corrosion visible and the traces look great.
I replaced some components most of which were connected to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> due to some bad looking caps.
Replaced <CAPACITOR>C7317</CAPACITOR>/18, <CAPACITOR>C7310</CAPACITOR>/11,<RESISTOR>R7311</RESISTOR>,<CHIP>U7310</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C7620</CAPACITOR>/22
<CHIP>U7200</CHIP> Pins 7-10 didn't look good so I replaced the entire chip but that still didn't solve this.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: power cycling or pulsing voltages are sucks, they can be anything when there are no visible damage on the board. i hate fixing these boards. i hope you can fix it. :)

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: This board does have some visible damage since it came in contact with liquid. What are the most common areas to look for with this issue?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: The usual, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> data line termination resistors and traces, clock chip area, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
The <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> termination resistors all measured fine and the traces as well, I replaced the clock chip and <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> even though they looked fine. I put another bios on the board and it still does the cycling.
I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR>,<CAPACITOR>C7630</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C7624</CAPACITOR>, and <RESISTOR>R7631</RESISTOR> since they didn't look to great and the board is still doing the same thing.

What else do you think could be causing this?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
[QUOTE="ytesfay80, post: 22420"]The <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> termination resistors all measured fine and the traces as well, I replaced the clock chip and <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> even though they looked fine. I put another bios on the board and it still does the cycling.
I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR>,<CAPACITOR>C7630</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C7624</CAPACITOR>, and <RESISTOR>R7631</RESISTOR> since they didn't look to great and the board is still doing the same thing.

What else do you think could be causing this?[/QUOTE]

What do PPBUS and S5 rails do when the board is not trying to power on, i.e. With only the battery connected?
This will not lead me to be able to answer questions but it [I][B]may[/B][/I] eliminate possible causes in your hunt for the fault.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: Its time to start providing diode mode readings to all power rails. This may help in identifying shorts.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: When I plugged the battery in <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> was around 2.2v and quickly went towards 1.55v and stayed around there. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> showed 0v.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: Resistance to GND on PPBUS? Checked sense resistors around <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
I checked the sense resistors and it was way too high then I noticed that the caps/resistors looked a little dark so I replaced the entire area as well as the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>. Now PPBUS is steady 12.6v and cpu vcore/<SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> was steady as well.
I can feel the cpu getting warm so I know its turning on but for some reason the screen is not showing anything. I plugged in a known working late 2013 screen and that didn't turn on either. I'm not too familiar with the screen circuit for these Retinas but here are some measurements I got from the lcd connector.

J8300- Pins 3/4 - 5.15v
Pins 1 and 28/29/30 all gave me 0v

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: 2013 LCD will not work! USB mouse lighting up? Chime?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: Okay. The usb mouse was lighting up but I didn't hear any chime.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: Come on engage the brain, PRAM RESET, this stuff you should know by now.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
Okay I plugged in my spare keyboard and did the pram reset but nothing happened. I'm pretty sure the keyboard is working because I measured the kbd connector pins as I clicked the option key and the control key and they both went up to 3.42v as I pressed them.
I also tried to do the smc bypass and hook thunderbolt to my tv but that didn't work either.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: You use a USB keyboard to do this....Who know if the trackpad is even working which is needed for the keyboard to work.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
okay I didnt know the trackpad has to be working for the kbd to work. I plugged in my usb mouse again and I got no lights so I went and checked voltages again and found out there is no vcore or s3/s0 rails. <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> is present so now I have to figure why the rest of them aren't.

As far as the usb keyboard does it have to be an apple one? The only one I have is a very old Dell usb keyboard.

Update:
Here are some measurements I got from <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> which lead me to finding out there is no voltage on  <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
Pins 12,22,23 and 29 all have the correct voltages present
Pins 20/21 had 3.4v 
Pins 2,4,5 show 0v as well as 0v on <RESISTOR>R8179</RESISTOR>

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: I have no idea what you are doing. Now there is even no S3 power? I'm sorry but I have no idea what is going on here....

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
Alright with no external components plugged in I measured <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> as soon as I plug the charger in and I saw it show 3.4v for a quick second. Do you know what would usually cause it to pulse like that?

I did replace <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> when I was first diagnosing the board so I'm not sure if this could have caused any of these problems.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: Yes anything can cause power cycling, the usual are the clock chip, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> termination resistors and traces. Check all traces between <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and the resistors too!!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
Okay so <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> didn't look too well on the Pin 5 side so I replaced it along with <TRANSISTOR>Q7311</TRANSISTOR> for good measure and now it turns on and runs perfectly fine. Thanks
Do you have an idea how that could have caused these issues?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: Like I said, anything can cause power cycling. It is just the CPU not starting and the machine trying again and again.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: But what about when I getting cpu vcore but the machine wasn't chiming or the screen wasn't turning on. Could <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR>/11 caused that?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
if you get S0, do you get <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>?
I notice you mentioned you messed with <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>. if improperly soldered or not working correctly it could cause All S0 but no chime.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: The machine is now working and all rails are present I was just asking to keep as a mental note
